Vinod Hugo -- gohugo.io en-us © 2018 Wed, 20 Apr 2016 00:00:00 -0600 Stochastic Motion Planning Using Successive Convexification and Probabilistic Occupancy Functions https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/cdc2018/ Thu, 20 Sep 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/cdc2018/ ARCH-COMP18 Category Report: Stochastic Modelling https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/arch2018/ Fri, 27 Jul 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/arch2018/ Multiple Pursuer-Based Intercept Via Forward Stochastic Reachability https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/acc2018/ Wed, 27 Jun 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/acc2018/ Scalable Stochastic Reachability: Theory, Computation, and Control https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-05-berkeley/ Tue, 15 May 2018 00:00:00 -0600 https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-05-berkeley/ Multiple Pursuer-Based Intercept Via Forward Stochastic Reachability (ACC 2018) https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-06-milwaukee/ Mon, 07 May 2018 00:00:00 -0600 https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-06-milwaukee/ Optimal Trade-Off Analysis for Efficiency and Safety in the Spacecraft Rendezvous and Docking Problem (NAASS 2018) https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-06-santafe/ Mon, 07 May 2018 00:00:00 -0600 https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-06-santafe/ Safety for stochastic systems: Terminal stochastic reach-avoid problem https://abyvinod.github.io/post/terminal-stochastic-reach-avoid-problem/ Sun, 06 May 2018 00:00:00 -0600 https://abyvinod.github.io/post/terminal-stochastic-reach-avoid-problem/

Automation, typically, refers to the use of an onboard computer to drives a system to optimize some objective. It makes our day-to-day life simpler and efficient, for example, in transportation (autopilot systems and self-driving cars), space applications (spacecraft rendezvous and docking problem), biomedical applications, power grid, and the list goes on and on. However, as we hand over more and more control to the automation, we naturally seek guarantees of safety and performance. After all, we do not want to spend billions of dollar in R&D and develop an automation that may cause harm.

Why is providing safety guarantees in automated control systems for real-world problems hard?

In control theory, we attack real-world problems by formulating a mathematical model and studying its relevant properties. The two key challenges in providing the desired safety guarantees for real-world systems are stochasticity and high-dimensionality.

Stochasticity in our models help us capture human inputs (like actions of the other drivers on the street for the self-driving car problem), disturbance effects (like weather in air navigation/power grid systems), varying parameters (like patient parameters in biomedical devices), and other unmodelled phenomena (like simplifications1 done in complex system models seen in space and power applications). High-dimensional systems evolve as a function of a larger set of states, and thereby allowing the mathematical model to be closer to the reality compared to their low-dimensional models.

We pose the problem of safety as Problem A is: Design a controller that maximizes the probability of satisfaction of the following constraints under bounded control space for the system:

  1. Ensure that the system reaches the target set at a finite time horizon (not before). (Reach constraint)
  2. Ensure that the system stays within the safe set at a finite time horizon (not before). (Reach constraint)

Problem A is accompanied by the following information:

  1. the initial state of the system,
  2. the safe set,
  3. the target set,
  4. the stochastic system dynamics along with the bounded control space.

Problem A is called the terminal hitting-time stochastic reach-avoid problem1. It is a special class of verification problems, which has been well studied for the past couple of decades in computer science as well as control theory.

Safety verification explained via an example: the spacecraft rendezvous and docking problem

Consider the spacecraft rendezvous and docking problem. As shown in Figure 2, we have two satellites — a “chief” satellite and a “deputy” satellite. To simplify the study, we consider the dynamics of the deputy satellites relative to the chief satellite, and in contrast to a true mathematical model, we consider a simpler stochastic model to describe the relative dynamics.

Our safety and performance requirements are:

  1. Ensure that the deputy satellite reaches the chief satellite at a finite time horizon (not before). (Reach constraint)
  2. Ensure that the deputy satellite remains in a line-of-sight cone till it satisfies objective 1. (Avoid constraint)

We are interested in solving Problem A: Design a controller that maximizes the probability of satisfaction of the above objectives 1 and 2 under bounded control space for the deputy satellite.

In this case, we have the following information:

  1. the initial state of the deputy satellite,
  2. the safe set (definition of the line-of-sight cone),
  3. the target set (a box around the origin),
  4. the relative stochastic dynamics of the deputy satellite with respect to the chief satellite.

Note that the avoid constraint is motivated by the fact that sensing and localization capabilities are limited in space applications.

  1. See Summers, Sean, and John Lygeros. “Verification of discrete time stochastic hybrid systems: A stochastic reach-avoid decision problem.” Automatica, Vol. 46, No. 12, 2010, pp. 1951-1961. ^
Scalable stochastic reachability techniques https://abyvinod.github.io/project/sr/ Sat, 05 May 2018 00:00:00 -0600 https://abyvinod.github.io/project/sr/

Table of Contents

  • Problem formulation
  • Solutions proposed
  • Awards and recognition
  • Future work

Problem formulation

Real-world problems are typically stochasticity and high-dimensional. Stochasticity may arise from human actions, unmodeled phenomena (e.g. weather), and uncertainty in system parameters. As we strive for more automation, it is natural ask for guarantees of safety and performance, which is a hard problem. This project aims to provide scalable and tractable guarantees of safety and performance in real world problems, described as continuous-state discrete-time stochastic models.

For these models, this project tries to address the following problems:

  1. Forward stochastic reachability problem: For an uncontrolled stochastic system and a given initial state, what is:
    1. the set of possible values1 of the state in future?
    2. the likelihood associated with it?
  2. Backward stochastic reachability problem: For a stochastic system with bounded control authority and a set of (possibly time-varying) constraints on the state,
    1. What is the maximum likelihood of satisfying these constraints from a given initial state?
    2. How can we design a controller that achieves this computed likelihood while satisfying the specified control bounds?
    3. What is the set of initial states that can achieve a specified likelihood of safety?
  3. Stochastic optimal control with safety as a priority: Can we design controllers that maximize safety while simultaneously minimize an additional cost function, for example, fuel costs?

Solutions proposed

I have used Fourier transforms to answer Problem 1.

To answer Problem 2, I have proposed:

  1. a recursion-free, parallelizable, and anytime approach that relies on Fourier transforms, convex optimization, and gradient-free optimization techniques to propose an open-loop underapproximation of the probability, the controller synthesis, and the set, and
  2. (developed in collaboration with Joseph Gleason), a set operation-based approach to compute an underapproximation of the stochastic reach-avoid by solving a related robust reach-avoid problem.

I have used bicriterion optimization techniques to address Problem 3.

Awards and recognition

During my PhD research under the advisement of Dr. Meeko Oishi, I have developed scalable and grid-free techniques to answer these problems. This work has won multiple recognitions:

  1. Best student paper award at 2017 ACM Proceedings of Hybrid Systems: Computation and Control, Pittsburgh, USA.
  2. Finalist for the best paper award at 2018 ACM Proceedings of Hybrid Systems: Computation and Control, Porto, Portugal.

Future work

  1. I am building, in collaboration with Joseph Gleason, a MATLAB toolbox to perform stochastic reachability computations using the proposed methods.
  2. I am also extending these results to more richer classes of systems and control policies.
  1. This set is actually the support of the random vector describing the state. ^
Stochastic motion planning https://abyvinod.github.io/project/stochastic-motion-planning/ Sat, 05 May 2018 00:00:00 -0600 https://abyvinod.github.io/project/stochastic-motion-planning/ User-interface design for human-automation systems https://abyvinod.github.io/project/user-interface/ Sat, 05 May 2018 00:00:00 -0600 https://abyvinod.github.io/project/user-interface/ Optimal trade-off analysis for efficiency and safety in the spacecraft rendezvous and docking problem https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/naass2018/ Sun, 01 Apr 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/naass2018/ Scalable Underapproximative Verification of Stochastic LTI Systems Using Convexity and Compactness https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/hscc2018/ Sun, 01 Apr 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/hscc2018/

This paper was a finalist for the HSCC 2018 best paper award.

The main contributions of this paper was:

  • Sufficient conditions for the convexity and compactness of the stochastic reach-avoid sets (set of safe1 initial states for stochastic systems under bounded control authority) for LTI systems
  • Tractable and scalable polytopic underapproximation by utilizing the “oracle” discussed in CSSL 2017 paper
  • Sufficient conditions for bang-bang safe policies.
  1. Safety is defined as being able to reach a target set at the time horizon and stay within the safe set during the rest of the time horizon. ^
Scalable Stochastic Reachability: Theory, Computation, and Control https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-03-02-washington/ Fri, 02 Mar 2018 00:00:00 -0700 https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-03-02-washington/ Safe autonomy via Stochastic Reachability https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-02-01-austin/ Thu, 01 Feb 2018 00:00:00 -0700 https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-02-01-austin/ Safe autonomy via Stochastic Reachability https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-01-10-iisc/ Wed, 10 Jan 2018 00:00:00 -0700 https://abyvinod.github.io/talk/2018-01-10-iisc/ <<<<<<< HEAD ======= Scalable Underapproximation for Stochastic Reach-Avoid Problem for High-Dimensional LTI Systems using Fourier Transforms https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/cssl2017/ Fri, 01 Dec 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://abyvinod.github.io/publication/cssl2017/

This paper tackles the terminal hitting-time stochastic reach-avoid problem. It proposes:

  1. Sufficient conditions under which such a controller exists
  2. An oracle that computes an open-loop optimal controller that achieves an (optimized) lower bound — the open-loop underapproximation — on the maximum stochastic reach-avoid probability
